text.p: Following are some of the major events to have occurred on October 29 in history.
1507 - Fernando Alvarez de Toledo, Duke of Alba, born. A Spanish soldier and statesman who was a tyrannical governor general of the Netherlands, he led a successful invasion of Portugal.
1618 - Sir Walter Raleigh, English adventurer who was a favourite of Queen Elizabeth I, was executed in London for treason.
1740 - James Boswell, Scottish diarist and biographer noted for his two-volume chronicle of the life of Samuel Johnson, born.
1787 - The first performance of Mozart's "Don Giovanni" took place in Prague.
1811 - (Jean Joseph Charles) Louis Blanc, pioneering French utopian socialist, born.
1814 - The first steam-powered warship, the USS Fulton, was launched at New York. It was designed by Robert Fulton.
1879 - Franz von Papen, German statesman and diplomat who was named chancellor in 1932 and was instrumental in helping Adolf Hitler to power in 1933, born.
1888 - The Constantinople Convention on Free Navigation of the Suez Canal was signed.
1889 - The British South Africa Company, headed by Cecil Rhodes, was granted royal charter by the British government giving it extensive powers and rights in the area which became Rhodesia.
1897 - Joseph Goebbels, minister of propaganda for the German Third Reich under Adolf Hitler, born.
1923 - Turkey became a republic under its first president, nationalist leader Kemal Ataturk.
1929 - Prices virtually collapsed at the New York Stock Exchange on Wall Street. The day became known as "Black Tuesday" and lead to the Great Depression of the 1930's.
1950 - King Gustav V of Sweden died and was succeeded by his son Gustav VI.
1956 - Israeli troops crossed the border with Egypt and swept into the Sinai peninsula toward the Suez Canal.
1964 - The United Republic of Tanganyika, Zanzibar and Pemba changed its name to Tanzania.

1972 - The Black September guerrilla group hijacked a Lufthansa Boeing 727 as it flew over Turkey and demanded the release of three colleagues still held for the massacre of Israeli athletes at the Olympic Games.
1973 - Klaus Altmann, wanted in France for war crimes under the name of Klaus Barbie, was released after nearly eight months in a Bolivian jail.
1977 - The Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, Cardinal Stefan Wyszynski, and Communist party leader Edward Gierek met officially for the first time.
1980 - A declaration by Communist party Vice-Chairman Deng Xiaoping that Chairman Mao made serious political mistakes during his rule was made public.

1982 - The trial of Lindy Chamberlain, whose baby daughter disappeared in the Australian outback in 1980, ended when she was convicted of murder. She had claimed a wild dog took the child. After several appeals she was finally pardoned in 1987.
1990 - Norway's centre-right government collapsed after a dispute over how far to link the economy to the European Community.
1995 - 289 people were killed when a crowded underground train caught fire between stations in Baku, Azerbaijan.
